@awasum, @vorburger, @ptuomola is it for you?

In theory, given that AFAIK there are no integration tests, anyone using Fineract's `S3ContentRepository` should probably manually test the upgrade of this library. Seeing however that is is only a minor version bump, I'll assume it's compatible enough, and just go ahead and merged this.

I've exceptionally "self merged" this PR, because technically I'm hereby reviewing and approving a change made by Dependabot so with green Travis, we got 4-eyes on this - my 2 eyes, and 1 each from Travis and Dependabot.. :rofl: 

Swagger unfortunately isn't really finished anyway (see FINERACT-733), so the "risk" here is very low.

I'm not clear about what test coverage with have for the OAuth support, but I suspect zilch, zero, nothing. Would anyone actually using Fineract's OAuth support be willing to test if things still work after this upgrade? And ideally contribute a real non-regression test for it for the future...
@percyashu I've just merged #846 so you're unblocked now - I look forward to reviewing this, once you manage to make it pass the build!

> @awasum, @vorburger, @ptuomola is it for you?

I would prefer to see the Flyway upgrade raised a separate PR with ref. to FINERACT-810. Make FINERACT-810 a blocker for FINERACT-897 if that is the case (I'm assuming that you have found that it is).

Let us then clarify by updating both the title of FINERACT-897 and the commit comment in this PR to more precisely express what exactly this is, and isn't... I think what we have concluded in FINERACT-897 is that this now actually is NOT (anymore) a "Upgrade to mysql v8", but... "make SQL and code work on both MySQL 5.7 as well as more recent versions such as v8" - kind of wording?

As for reviewing the (massive, wow, how did you do that, hats off!) SQL diff in this PR, I'm not the most qualified - I'm hoping other parties interested in MySQL would chime in to review this better than I could.

> I would prefer to see the Flyway upgrade raised a separate PR with ref. to FINERACT-810. Make FINERACT-810 a blocker for FINERACT-897 if that is the case (I'm assuming that you have found that it is).

Not a problem. I can chop that change off this PR and raise a different PR for it.

> As for reviewing the (massive, wow, how did you do that, hats off!) SQL diff in this PR, I'm not the most qualified - I'm hoping other parties interested in MySQL would chime in to review this better than I could.

It was not much of a struggle. All the scripts are basically thesame as before. I just updated some deprecated features such int(10).. etc. Most respect to those who wrote the scripts. They are quite robust.

Hey @vorburger could you make this as draft, since I tested the test written they don't comply and need to re-write them again. (real integration test)
Wooow...this finally worked? Thank you both very much. What happened that drizzle or something else stopped having problems wrt Flyway? Just curious...is it the new upgrades we made ?

@vorburger ...Ohhh... merged this but it failed with an error:
Invalid workflow file:
https://github.com/apache/fineract/actions/runs/101369009

Please...help to check it.

You have uncommented the checkstyle modules, I think we need to uncomment them one by one, and enforce them so that the build wont fail.
Also, I suggest not adding new modules and currently focus on what were already decided by @vorburger 

What do you suggest?

> You have uncommented the checkstyle modules, I think we need to uncomment them one by one, and enforce them so that the build wont fail.
> Also, I suggest not adding new modules and currently focus on what were already decided by @vorburger
> 
> What do you suggest?

I Understand that, but the modules suggested by @vorburger are from https://github.com/opendaylight/odlparent/blob/master/checkstyle/src/main/resources/odl_checks.xml and while I was going through the checksytle docs I saw a usage example that meets the google coding conventions here https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/56307daaf4921243c16a874b844757961618003b/src/main/resources/google_checks.xml. 

I have just removed something's not need and added what was missing in some places
Both checkstyle examples are the same but one is a little more specific on what is to check that's what I went in for.

Hm, nice, thanks! Super cool how it already found those clear real bugs in hashCode(), no? But... we should address all the problems, not use SuppressWarnings. Or merge this, and then fix them all... but will we? These kinds of things often get forgotten... May I try to be a PITA ;-) and suggest we fix them all here already, before merging?
Hello. I'll only review this PR if it passes the build checks. Thanks for understanding!

@Wandji69 thank you for the explanation :D I got it now, on the other side, I have already laid a plan for implementing and enforcing "current check styles", We can definitely add more/make the current more specific, but I would prefer focusing on what we already have planned? What do you think? 
I like the idea of adding more/making them more specific. I will start implementing them from 14-15may(as a part of GSoC), after which you can take over to make them more specific to improve code quality even further(Which will be certainly great and needed) 

If you like my plan to make the codebase more beautiful, you can give me LGTM? 

FYI @vorburger 

-thanks 
Manthan

Wandji Collins. Pick something else from the backlog to work on. Manthan Surkaris claiming this one for this GSoC work. Next time Manthan Surkar, dont wait for someone to show interest on an issue before you self assign to yourself. Pick one or 2 issues at a time to work on and give room for others. You can go through the issue tracker and pick the issues you are interested in...so that people dont get confused. One person should own and work on a single issue in most cases.
Okay @awasum, I will close this issue now and let @thesmallstar take over.

@vorburger Unfortunately I'm not an expert on Guava... but looking at the dependencies:

- The only reference in Fineract source to Guava that I was able to find is in some comments in org.apache.fineract.infrastructure.bulkimport.populator, and everything seems to compile OK even if I remove the Guava dependency from dependencies.gradle. Do we even use this in Fineract?

- checkstyle is already expecting 0.29
- If we upgrade Mustache to latest version (0.9.6), it no longer seems to depend on Guava

So after that, it's only Swagger and ActiveMQ that are expecting Guava 27 / 28 but would get 29. Looking at the changelog I did not see anything that made me worried, but of course you never know...
I don't know much about this. I'll just pull @vorburger to have a look

@nemux anything we can do to help you wrap this up?

PS: If you think adding a test for this is too much to ask for this PR, I also don't really mind at all if we merge this without a test (once you made it pass the build, of course; and provided feedback the other more minor points raised above), and then create another JIRA and you perhaps contribute the test in a later PR. If Email sending is currently broken (it is?), then I guess fixing it even without a test yet is still better than having it broken! :smile:

Looks great to me!
The code itself looks good to me. I haven't hit this particular problem myself, so can't comment on whether it fixes the issue - but it does look like a sensible thing to do.

As this change updates a lot of the Flyway SQL migration scripts, I was just wondering: what happens with existing databases where these scripts have already been ran?  I'm assuming Flyway will not try to reapply the scripts that it thinks it has already ran. Will their column types be converted to supported somehow magically by MySQL as part of their MySQL upgrade? 

Or will we end up with two types of schemas: ones which have been created with the Flyway scripts after these changes have been committed and therefore work with MySQL 8 - and other ones which have been created before, and continue to use the deprecated features?
LGTM!
Looks good to me - much cleaner than the previous code
If I am not wrong, @percyashu  has this planned for his summer in GSoC?

Just wish to clarify that the changes here are literally very minor. The schemas and architectures are basically thesame as they were before: same names, same rules etc. The only changes that are done here are purely syntactic(Ex: changing deprecated declaration int(2) to the int which works fine with both v8 and v5.7 also changing charsets). Same logic, different syntax and again even the syntatic changes are minor. Unless I'm mistaken, but this will still look thesame in the DB once migrated so I can hardly see an issue here.
I don't know if you follow??

This looks clean..But i dont understand completely whats happening here. @vorburger Go ahead and self merge. You know what you are doing.
